title: Energy Matrix
html:
Brazil has the cleanest and most diverse energy matrix on the planet.

Here , 46%   energy is generated by renewable sources, a percentage more than four times higher than the average of OECD countries. Worldwide, the average is 14.2% of renewable sources in the countries' energy matrix.

If only electricity is computed, the index rises to 82%   renewable energy, an index three times higher than that found among OECD countries.

  • Much of the electricity generated in Brazil comes from hydroelectric plants. Wind energy has also been growing a lot, contributing to our electricity matrix to remain, for the most part, renewable.

Brazil developed ethanol derived from sugar cane, renewable source that fixes carbon in the soil and is a significant and relevant alternative for worldwide mobility.

Useful information

  • Non-renewable sources of energy are largely responsible for the emission of greenhouse gases (GHG).
  • Energy matrix represents the set of energy sources available to move cars, prepare food on the stove and generate electricity. The electrical matrix is ​​formed by the set of sources available only for the generation of electrical energy. Thus, the electrical matrix is ​​part of the energy matrix.

Emissions

While the rich countries were industrializing, Brazil was eminently agricultural, contributing very little, if anything, to the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the Earth's atmosphere (only 1%).

We are currently responsible for less than 3% of total global emissions . Thus, Brazil has contributed, and continues to contribute, to the maintenance of the climate on the planet.

The European Union accounts for almost 14% of emissions, much of which is related to the burning of fossil fuels.

The country is committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 37% by 2025 and by 43% by 2030, compared to 2005 figures.

Another commitment is to achieve neutrality climate change in 2060, with the possibility of bringing forward the deadline to 2050 if significant resources are made available that contribute in this regard.

Between 2006 and 2017, the country avoided the emission of 7.8 billion tons of carbon. Based on the value of carbon credit traded in California, that equates to $ 294 billion. To date, Brazil has received only about 1 billion.

This amount is equivalent to five years of net emissions in the country.

International agreements

Copenhagen (2009): reduce emissions by 1.24 gigatonnes by 2020.

  • In 2018, only with the reduction of deforestation in the Amazon and the Cerrado, emissions had already been mitigated by 2.28 gigatonnes. (Source: Inpe)

Paris (2015), targets until 2030 (Sources: MME and ANP):

  • Increase in the share of biofuels to 18% in the energy matrix (target already achieved).
  • 45% of renewable sources in the energy matrix. In 2021, the country had already reached 46.1%.
  • Increase in the share of renewables in the energy matrix, except hydroelectric plants, to 28%. In 2021 the rate was already 32.7%.
